intro: Eucalyptus corticosa, commonly known as the rough-barked gum, is a species of eucalyptus native to southern Australia. It is characterized by its smooth, greyish bark that peels in strips, giving it a distinctive appearance. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, white powdery coating. Its flowers are usually pale yellow or cream, clustered in umbels, and attract a variety of pollinators. The plant is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in coastal regions where it contributes to local biodiversity.
